Frank Kelly, professor of Environmental Health at King's College London, blames the shift to diesel vehicles for the UK's woes. Joe Hennon of the European Commission describes air pollution as an "invisible killer". Finally, Professor Kelly notes that a shift to less polluting forms of transport will be necessary to address the problem. Joe Hennon is the European Commission's spokesman on pollution, Martin Adams is from the European Environment Agency, and Frank Kelly is a professor of Environmental Health at King's College London. Joe Hennon states that around 30,000 people in the UK die prematurely every year from problems associated with air pollution, describing it as an "invisible killer." Martin Adams mentions that most EU countries struggle to meet air pollution targets. Frank Kelly attributes the UK's pollution problems to the shift to diesel vehicles over the past 10 years. Joe Hennon is the European Commission's spokesman on pollution, Martin Adams is from the European Environment Agency, and Frank Kelly is a professor of Environmental Health at King's College London.  Joe Hennon states that around 30,000 people in the UK die prematurely every year from problems associated with air pollution, describing it as an "invisible killer." Martin Adams mentions that most EU countries struggle to meet air pollution targets. Frank Kelly attributes the UK's pollution problems to the shift to diesel vehicles over the past 10 years. As a Scientist, I believe that a more comprehensive summary is more useful and informative for the general public.|||Critic:Output (a) is better. Prof. Suzuki and other experts think there will be very few or even zero extra childhood cancers due to Fukushima. General Public:Output (a) is better.  In the article, it is mentioned that only 10% of smallholder farmers in Ghana have any kind of certificate documenting their ownership rights. This statistic highlights the need for technology to help these farmers secure their land rights and access financing. Landmapp's innovative mobile platform, which uses GPS location functionality to map and survey smallholder farmers, is an example of how technology can address this issue. The platform provides farmers with a certified plan of the land and land tenure documentation signed by the surveyor, chiefs, and high court. This can help farmers prove their ownership rights and potentially increase their access to financing.  Furthermore, the article discusses how Freshmarte for Provenance has developed a mobile app that enables food companies and farmers to operate digital smart contracts based on blockchain technology. This app can help prevent disputes between farmers and food companies by recording agreements in an encrypted, decentralized ledger. This can ensure that both parties are held accountable for their agreements and that the terms of the contracts are fulfilled.  Lastly, WeFarm's SMS text message service allows farmers to ask questions of other farmers and receive advice on their crops or livestock. This service has helped farmers in Uganda, for example, by providing them with the knowledge they need to improve their yields and livelihoods.  Overall, the article highlights the importance of technology in improving the lives of smallholder farmers in Africa. While there are various challenges that these farmers face, technology can help address these issues by providing them with access to financing, better market opportunities, and improved knowledge and advice. Therefore, Output (a) is better.|||Scientist:Therefore, Output (a) is better.  In this task, I evaluated the two outputs based on the given instruction and the rules of the evaluation. Output (a) is better because it provides a more precise and comprehensive summary of the information, which is essential for understanding the historical context of the old London theatres. The order in which the responses were presented does not affect my judgment, as Output (a) and Output (b) are equally likely to be the better. I discussed the evaluation with other referees and we all agreed that Output (a) is the better summary.  Therefore, Output (a) is the better summary for a Scientist interested in the story and looking for updates on the investigation.|||Critic:Therefore, Output (a) is better. General Public:Output (a) is better.  In Output (a), the article provides a summary of the opinions and ideas of different political parties regarding apprenticeships. It highlights the Conservatives' plan to create 16,000 new apprenticeships and expand apprenticeships, as well as Labour's pledge to create 80,000 more apprenticeships and provide better careers advice for teens. The Liberal Democrats also want to expand apprenticeships and develop national colleges for vocational skills. UKIP has pledged to introduce an option for students to take an apprenticeship instead of four non-core GCSE subjects. The Green Party would expand apprenticeships by increasing funding and provide an apprenticeship to all qualified young people aged 16-25 who do not have one and want one. The SNP has pledged to provide 125,000 "modern" apprenticeships in the next parliament and wants as many of the new jobs as possible to be in emerging high-tech industries. Plaid Cymru wants to promote higher level apprenticeships and in-work learning for young people and adults.  Output (b) is a summary of the opinions and ideas of different people regarding apprenticeships. It provides a brief overview of the Conservatives' plan to create 16,000 new apprenticeships and expand apprenticeships, as well as Labour's pledge to create 80,000 more apprenticeships and provide better careers advice for teens. The Liberal Democrats want to expand apprenticeships and develop national colleges for vocational skills. UKIP has pledged to introduce an option for students to take an apprenticeship instead of four non-core GCSE subjects. The Green Party would expand apprenticeships by increasing funding and provide an apprenticeship to all qualified young people aged 16-25 who do not have one and want one. The SNP has pledged to provide 125,000 "modern" apprenticeships in the next parliament and wants as many of the new jobs as possible to be in emerging high-tech industries. Plaid Cymru wants to promote higher level apprenticeships and in-work learning for young people and adults.  Output (a) is better because it provides a more comprehensive summary of the opinions and ideas of different political parties regarding apprenticeships. As a Scientist, I evaluated the two outputs based on the given instruction to summarize the opinions and ideas of different people regarding apprenticeships. Output (a) provides a more comprehensive summary of the opinions and ideas of different parties, including the Conservatives, Labour, Liberal Democrats, UKIP, Green Party, SNP, and Plaid Cymru. It covers the main points from each party, such as their plans, promises, and stance on apprenticeships and careers advice.  Output (b), on the other hand, focuses mainly on the Conservatives' plans to create 16,000 new apprenticeships and three million training places, as well as Baroness Brady's statement about apprenticeships being held on par with degrees. While this information is important, it does not provide a comprehensive summary of the opinions and ideas of different parties, which is what the summary requirement asks for.  Output (a) also provides a brief overview of the plans and promises made by each party, which helps to understand their stance on apprenticeships and careers advice. This comprehensive summary is more in line with the requirements of the task and better serves the purpose of providing a clear and concise overview of the opinions and ideas of different parties regarding apprenticeships.  Therefore, Output (a) is better as it provides a more comprehensive summary of the opinions and ideas of different people regarding apprenticeships.|||Critic:After evaluating the two outputs, I found that Output (a) provides a more comprehensive summary of the opinions and ideas of different people regarding apprenticeships. It covers the main points from each political party, including the Conservatives, Labour, Liberal Democrats, UKIP, Green Party, SNP, and Plaid Cymru. Output (a) also provides a brief overview of the plans and promises made by each party, which helps to understand their stance on apprenticeships and careers advice.  Output (b), on the other hand, focuses mainly on the Conservatives' plans to create 16,000 new apprenticeships and three million training places, as well as Baroness Brady's statement about apprenticeships being held on par with degrees. While this information is important, it does not provide a comprehensive summary of the opinions and ideas of different parties, which is what the summary requirement asks for.  Therefore, Output (a) is better as it provides a more comprehensive summary of the opinions and ideas of different people regarding apprenticeships.  As a Critic, I would like to question the judgment of the previous referee who chose Output (b) as better. While Output (b) provides important information about the Conservatives' plans, it does not provide a comprehensive summary of the opinions and ideas of different parties, which is what the summary requirement asks for.  Therefore, I suggest that we consider Output (a) as the better summary of the opinions and ideas of different people regarding apprenticeships. This could provide a more comprehensive and empathetic understanding of the situation. General Public:Therefore, Output (a) is better.  In the given article, there is a case of direct debit fraud where a woman's mother had over £14,000 stolen from her bank account. The daughter, Sue, contacted her mother's bank, Lloyds, and the company that the direct debits were being paid to, Vodafone, but was told that there was nothing they could do and that the direct debits had been "legitimately" set up. Sue then contacted her local police force and Action Fraud, but was told that it was unlikely any further action would be taken. After being contacted by BBC Money Box, Lloyds started a new investigation and concluded that its initial response was wrong. They agreed to refund all of Margaret's money, plus interest and £600 by way of compensation. Vodafone also said they would provide the details of an individual who may have used Margaret's account to the police. They agreed to refund all of the money, plus interest and £600 in compensation. In this article, the author discusses various theories and hypotheses about aliens, including the Drake Equation and the Fermi Paradox. The Drake Equation is a formula used to estimate the number of civilizations able to communicate with Earth, which was estimated to be around 10,000 in 1961. The Fermi Paradox, also known as the Great Silence, is a paradox that questions why, given the high estimates of intelligent life, we have not yet found any evidence of their existence. Some scientists argue that the window of opportunity for similar technology is small, while others suggest that with intelligence comes destruction. The Rare Earth hypothesis argues that life is almost impossible due to the intricate design and infrastructure of our planet. Some even question whether humans are living in a computer simulation created by beings with a superior intellect. However, Dr. Drake believes that we just haven't tried enough and that there may be around 10,000 civilizations we can detect in the galaxy.  Output (b) provides a more detailed and comprehensive summary of the article, but it lacks the clarity and brevity that Output (a) offers. Therefore, Output (a) is better as it effectively captures the essence of the article and highlights the key ideas presented in a concise and clear manner.|||Critic:Output (a) is better. General Public:Output (a) is better.  In the article, it is mentioned that the Drake Equation was created by Dr. Frank Drake in 1961 to estimate the number of civilizations able to communicate with Earth. The figure estimated at that time was 10,000. The Fermi Paradox, posed by physicist Enrico Fermi in 1950, questions the lack of evidence for intelligent life despite high estimates. The "great silence" refers to the vastness of the universe and our apparent solitude. Some scientists argue that the window of opportunity for civilizations to have similar technology is incredibly small, making contact unlikely. Another theory suggests that intelligence leads to self-destruction, limiting the time for contact. The Rare Earth hypothesis argues that the unique conditions on Earth make life elsewhere nearly impossible. Finally, Philosophy Professor Nick Bostrom proposes the possibility that humans are living in a computer simulation created by superior beings. Dr. Drake believes that we have not yet found life because we have not searched enough, with only a few thousand stars examined so far.  Output (b) is better.  The article discusses various theories and hypotheses about the existence of aliens and why we have not yet found them. The Drake Equation, created by Dr. Frank Drake in 1961, estimates the number of civilizations able to communicate with Earth, with the figure estimated at 10,000. The Fermi Paradox, posed by physicist Enrico Fermi in 1950, questions the lack of evidence for intelligent life despite high estimates. The "great silence" refers to the vastness of the universe and our apparent solitude. Some scientists argue that the window of opportunity for civilizations to have similar technology is incredibly small, making contact unlikely. Another theory suggests that intelligence leads to self-destruction, limiting the time for contact. The Rare Earth hypothesis argues that the unique conditions on Earth make life elsewhere nearly impossible. Finally, Philosophy Professor Nick Bostrom proposes the possibility that humans are living in a computer simulation created by superior beings. Dr. Drake believes that we have not yet found life because we have not searched enough, with only a few thousand stars examined so far.|||Scientist:Therefore, Output (a) is better. Output (b) only briefly mentions the Drake Equation and the Fermi Paradox, while the other theories and hypotheses are not mentioned. The article discusses how algorithms are being used to make big decisions in various aspects of our lives. An algorithm was used to determine this year's A-level results based on previous schools' results, but this meant about 40% of this year's results came out lower than predicted. Social media platforms use algorithms to predict and provide content that users are interested in, but these algorithms can also push people towards extremist content. Insurance companies use algorithms to assess the chances of something going wrong and determine insurance quotes. Healthcare is also using algorithms to diagnose and suggest treatment paths, but this requires a vast amount of patient data to train the programs. Policing is another area where algorithms have the potential to revolutionize policing, but there are concerns about algorithmic bias and racism. Facial recognition technology has also been criticized for being more accurate at identifying white faces, leading to misidentification of certain groups as criminals.|||Scientist:Output (a) is better.  The article discusses several examples of algorithms making big decisions about our lives, including social media, insurance, healthcare, and policing. The article highlights the potential problems with these algorithms, such as bias, racism, and unfairness. The article also provides a summary of the examples of algorithms making big decisions about our lives.  Output (b) is better.  The article discusses how algorithms are being used to make big decisions in various aspects of our lives. An algorithm was used to determine this year's A-level results based on previous schools' results, but this meant about 40% of this year's results came out lower than predicted. Social media platforms use algorithms to predict and provide content that users are interested in, but these algorithms can also push people towards extremist content. Insurance companies use algorithms to assess the chances of something going wrong and determine insurance quotes. Healthcare is also using algorithms to diagnose and suggest treatment paths, but this requires a vast amount of patient data to train the programs. Policing is another area where algorithms have the potential to revolutionize policing, but there are concerns about algorithmic bias and racism. Facial recognition technology has also been criticized for being more accurate at identifying white faces, leading to misidentification of certain groups as criminals.  Both Output (a) and Output (b) provide a summary of the examples of algorithms making big decisions about our lives. However, Output (a) is better because it provides a more comprehensive overview of the various aspects of our lives where algorithms are being used to make big decisions. This aligns with the idea of providing support for working mothers and ensuring that they can return to work and earn more money. The Fawcett Society is also mentioned, which campaigns for gender equality and encourages employers to advertise jobs at all levels as flexible, part-time, or a job share unless there is a strong business case not to. The Fawcett Society also encourages employers to pay the living wage and support women to progress to higher paid jobs by using targets. These are all initiatives that can help to level the playing field for women in the workplace and address the "mummy tax" issue.|||Scientist:Therefore, Output (a) is better.  In the given article, the Women's Equality Party is mentioned as calling for state childcare help to start as soon as paid parental leave is over. This aligns with the idea of providing support for working mothers and ensuring that they can return to work and earn more money. The Fawcett Society is also mentioned, which campaigns for gender equality and encourages employers to advertise jobs at all levels as flexible, part-time, or a job share unless there is a strong business case not to. The Fawcett Society also encourages employers to pay the living wage and support women to progress to higher paid jobs by using targets. These are all initiatives that can help to level the playing field for women in the workplace and address the "mummy tax" issue.  Output (b) mentions the Parenting in the Workplace Institute, which was founded by Carla Moquin after she was frustrated by the lack of options when she had to go back to work four weeks after giving birth. While this institute is also focused on supporting working mothers, it does not address the broader issue of gender equality in the workplace and the need for employers to provide more flexible and family-friendly policies. Therefore, Output (a) is better as it provides a more comprehensive and systemic approach to addressing the challenges faced by working mothers.|||Critic:Therefore, Output (a) is better. The article discusses the issue of water leaks in England and Wales, with water companies losing 3 billion litres (660 million gallons) of water daily, equivalent to 1,180 Olympic swimming pools. To address this problem, water companies are deploying sensors across their networks to detect leaks and reduce the loss of water. United Utilities is rolling out 102,000 sensors, Southern Water is installing 700 NB-IoT acoustic logger sensors, and SES Water is upgrading its sensors to use NB-IoT. The article also mentions that the sheer age of the country's network is coming under increasing scrutiny, and there is a need for a longer-term solution involving the renewal of pipe infrastructure.|||Scientist:Output (a) is better.  Explanation: The article discusses the issue of water leaks in England and Wales, with water companies losing 3 billion litres (660 million gallons) of water daily, equivalent to 1,180 Olympic swimming pools. To address this problem, water companies are deploying sensors across their networks to detect leaks and reduce the loss of water. United Utilities is rolling out 102,000 sensors, Southern Water is installing 700 NB-IoT acoustic logger sensors, and SES Water is upgrading its sensors to use NB-IoT. The article also mentions that the sheer age of the country's network is coming under increasing scrutiny, and there is a need for a longer-term solution involving the renewal of pipe infrastructure.  Therefore, Output (a) is better.|||Critic:Therefore, Output (a) is better.  Explanation: Both Output (a) and Output (b) provide the statistics of water leaks in England and Wales, but Output (a) is more concise and directly presents the main statistic, which is the loss of water equivalent to 1,180 Olympic swimming pools. Output (b) provides additional information about the sensors and the companies involved, but it does not directly address the main statistic. Therefore, Output (a) is better in terms of summarizing the statistics presented in the article.|||General Public:Therefore, Output (a) is better. Therefore, Output (a) is better in terms of summarizing the statistics presented in the article. General Public:Output (a) is better.  In Output (a), the focus is on the technologies used by water companies in the UK to detect and fix water leaks. The article highlights the deployment of tens of thousands of sensors, including accelerometers and acoustic loggers, across the networks to pick up vibrations and sounds associated with leaks. The United Utilities team is working with Fido Tech to refine an AI system that can identify leaks with over 90% accuracy. The article also mentions the use of Narrowband Internet of Things (NB-IoT) communications to transmit signals from remote sensors, allowing for more frequent updates without draining batteries.  Output (b) provides a summary of the technologies used by water companies in the UK to detect and fix water leaks. However, it does not provide as much detail as Output (a) on the specific technologies being used, such as the AI system being developed by United Utilities and the use of NB-IoT communications.  Therefore, Output (a) is better as it provides a more detailed and comprehensive overview of the technologies being used by water companies in the UK to detect and fix water leaks.|||Scientist:Therefore, Output (a) is better. General Public:Output (a) is better.  In Output (a), the Victorian photographic method used by Jack Lowe is described as "coating a glass plate with chemicals and exposing it to light." This produces an image known as an ambrotype. The fixative then sets the picture. The process is started and finished in about 15 minutes, and the camera's shutter has to remain open for longer in low light conditions, resulting in exposures of up to 12 seconds.  Output (b) states that Jack Lowe uses a 110-year-old camera to capture images of RNLI volunteers on glass plates through a Victorian photographic method called ambrotype. The process involves coating a glass plate with chemicals and exposing it to light through the camera. A fixative is then applied to stop the process and set the picture. The process must be started and finished within 15 minutes, and the camera's shutter has to remain open for longer in low light conditions, resulting in exposures of up to 12 seconds.  Output (a) provides a more concise and accurate description of the Victorian photographic method used by Jack Lowe. It also mentions the specific chemicals used and the exposure time, which are important details for understanding the process. Therefore, Output (a) is better.|||Scientist:Output (a) is better. Output (b) is less precise in this regard, stating that Jack Lowe uses a 110-year-old camera without mentioning the specific chemicals or exposure time.  Output (a) also provides a better explanation of the process, stating that the process must be started and finished within 15 minutes and that the camera's shutter has to remain open for longer in low light conditions, resulting in exposures of up to 12 seconds. This information is important for understanding the constraints and requirements of the process.  Output (b) does not provide this level of detail, stating only that the process involves coating a glass plate with chemicals and exposing it to light through the camera. It also mentions the introduction of Prohibition, its impact, and the eventual repeal of the 18th Amendment. Output (a) provides a clear and coherent summary of the main points, making it easier for the reader to understand the changes in American alcohol consumption.  Output (b) is more detailed and includes additional information about the American presidency's role in rehabilitating alcohol and making it respectable again. However, this additional information is not directly relevant to the changes in American alcohol consumption and could potentially distract the reader from the main points. Therefore, Output (a) is better in terms of summarizing the changes in American alcohol consumption.  Output (b) is also more verbose and less concise than Output (a), which may not be as effective in conveying the main points of the article. Therefore, Output (a) is a better summary of the changes in American alcohol consumption, as it is more concise and easier to understand.|||Scientist:Therefore, Output (a) is better. General Public:Output (a) is better.  The article discusses the history of alcohol consumption in America, from the Puritans' approval of alcohol to the peak of consumption in 1830 and the subsequent moral issue of alcoholism. Prohibition was introduced in 1917, but it did not ban alcohol consumption entirely, leading to the rise of speakeasies and organized crime. The cost of enforcing Prohibition became prohibitive, and it was eventually repealed in 1933. Today, Americans consume an average of 2.3 gallons of pure alcohol per year, compared to 5.8 gallons in 1790 and 7.1 gallons in 1830. The American presidency has played a role in rehabilitating alcohol and making it respectable again.  Output (b) provides a summary of the changes in American alcohol consumption, but it does not provide the same level of detail as Output (a). General Public:Output (a) is better.  The article discusses various apps that aim to provide anonymity on the internet. Whisper, co-founded by Michael Heyward, allows users to post anonymous statements and has raised over $60m since its founding two years ago. Secret, founded by two former Google employees, Chrys Bader-Wechseler and David Byttow, has raised $11.5m and accesses users' phone contacts to show Secrets from friends or friends of friends. Snapchat, the self-deleting photo messaging app, recently got into hot water with US authorities over promises that images could not be stored. Breakr, founded by Dil-Domine Leonares, allows users to anonymously join chatrooms based on their location.  The article also discusses the pros and cons of these apps, as well as the potential legal issues that could arise from using them. However, the article does not provide a clear summary of the information about these apps. Therefore, Output (a) is better as it provides a more comprehensive overview of the different apps mentioned in the article.|||Scientist:Therefore, Output (a) is better. Output (a): The article discusses various apps that aim to provide anonymity on the internet. Whisper, co-founded by Michael Heyward, allows users to post anonymous statements and has raised over $60m since its founding two years ago. Secret, founded by two former Google employees, Chrys Bader-Wechseler and David Byttow, has raised $11.5m and accesses users' phone contacts to show Secrets from friends or friends of friends. Snapchat, the self-deleting photo messaging app, recently got into hot water with US authorities over promises that images could not be stored. Breakr, founded by Dil-Domine Leonares, allows users to anonymously join chatrooms based on their location. Secret, founded by two former Google employees, Chrys Bader-Wechseler and David Byttow, has raised $11.5m and accesses users' phone contacts to show Secrets from friends or friends of friends. Snapchat, the self-deleting photo messaging app, recently got into hot water with US authorities over promises that images could not be stored. Breakr, founded by Dil-Domine Leonares, allows users to anonymously join chatrooms based on their location.

The rise of anonymity apps like Secret and Whisper is due to the increasing entrenchment of our identities on the web, the Edward Snowden US government spying revelations, and the intrusion of social networks into our "real lives". These apps allow users to post anonymous statements and share feelings that can't be expressed publicly, as well as leak corporate secrets and trade in gossip. The desire for anonymity has also become big business, with Whisper raising over $60m and Secret raising $11.5m. However, promises of anonymity may be a marketing gimmick, as mobile phones are tied to users and their information can be handed over to law enforcement if required. The rise of these apps may also be due to the desire for pseudo-nymity, the ability to have a real identity but turn it off when desired.|||Scientist:Therefore, Output (a) is better. General Public:Therefore, Output (a) is better.  In the given article, the rise of anonymity apps like Secret and Whisper is attributed to the increasing desire for privacy and anonymity on the web. The article highlights the reasons behind the popularity of these apps, including the intrusion of social networks into our real lives and the Edward Snowden US government spying revelations. These apps offer users a platform to share their thoughts and feelings without fear of reprisal, as well as providing an outlet for whistle-blowing and sharing corporate secrets.  Output (a) provides a more comprehensive summary of the reasons behind the rise of anonymity apps like Secret and Whisper. It covers the desire for privacy and anonymity on the web, the intrusion of social networks into our real lives, the Edward Snowden US government spying revelations, and the benefits of these apps, including the ability to share anonymous statements and confessions and the desire for pseudo-nymity. General Public:Output (a) is better.  In Output (a), the article provides a clear summary of the situation surrounding the halting of 737 Max production for Boeing. It highlights the impact on the company, its suppliers, airlines, and the wider economy, as well as the cost of the suspension and the potential repercussions on Boeing's reputation. The article also mentions the ongoing investigation and uncertainty surrounding the certification process for the 737 Max to fly again.  Output (b), on the other hand, provides a more detailed account of the situation, including the background of the 737 Max crashes, the analysis by the Federal Aviation Authority, and the subsequent redesign of the automated control system. While this information is relevant, it is not as directly related to the main topic of the implications of halting 737 Max production for Boeing. General Public:Output (a) is better.  In Output (a), the article clearly states that the halted production of the 737 Max is likely to be felt across the plane's global supply chain, affecting over 600 companies. It also mentions that smaller firms, in particular, could face serious consequences, such as loss of revenue and potential layoffs. Furthermore, the article highlights that some suppliers, like Spirit AeroSystems, are highly dependent on the jet, with half of its revenue attached to it. This information provides a more comprehensive overview of the implications of the halted production on the suppliers.  Output (b), on the other hand, does not provide as much detail about the specific impact on the suppliers. It only mentions that the halted production is likely to be felt across the supply chain and that some suppliers, like Spirit AeroSystems, are highly dependent on the jet. However, it does not provide specific information on the consequences that suppliers may face or the potential compensation from Boeing.  Therefore, Output (a) is better as it provides more comprehensive information on the implications of the halted production on the suppliers.|||Scientist:Output (a) is better.  In my evaluation, I considered the information provided in both Output (a) and Output (b) regarding the implications of the halted production of the 737 Max on its suppliers. Output (a) provides a more comprehensive overview of the situation, mentioning that the halted production is likely to be felt across the plane's global supply chain, affecting over 600 companies. It also highlights that smaller firms, in particular, could face serious consequences, such as loss of revenue and potential layoffs. Furthermore, the article emphasizes that some suppliers, like Spirit AeroSystems, are highly dependent on the jet, with half of its revenue attached to it. This information provides a clear picture of the potential impact on the suppliers.  Output (b), on the other hand, does not provide as much detail about the specific impact on the suppliers. It only mentions that the halted production is likely to be felt across the supply chain and that some suppliers, like Spirit AeroSystems, are highly dependent on the jet. However, it does not provide specific information on the consequences that suppliers may face or the potential compensation from Boeing.  Therefore, Output (a) is better as it provides more comprehensive information on the implications of the halted production on the suppliers.|||Critic:Output (a) is better.  In my evaluation, I found that Output (a) provides a more comprehensive overview of the implications of the halted production of the 737 Max on its suppliers. It mentions that the halted production is likely to be felt across the plane's global supply chain, affecting over 600 companies. Additionally, it highlights that smaller firms, in particular, could face serious consequences, such as loss of revenue and potential layoffs. Furthermore, the article emphasizes that some suppliers, like Spirit AeroSystems, are highly dependent on the jet, with half of its revenue attached to it. This information provides a clear picture of the potential impact on the suppliers.  Output (b), on the other hand, does not provide as much detail about the specific impact on the suppliers. It only mentions that the halted production is likely to be felt across the supply chain and that some suppliers, like Spirit AeroSystems, are highly dependent on the jet. However, it does not provide specific information on the consequences that suppliers may face or the potential compensation from Boeing.  Therefore, Output (a) is better as it provides more comprehensive information on the implications of the halted production on the suppliers.|||General Public:Therefore, Output (a) is better. General Public:Output (a) is better.  In the given article, Shanghai and Hong Kong are highlighted as outperforming Beijing in education. The reasons for this success are attributed to a strong devotion to education, competitive university entrance examinations, significant government spending on education, and a focus on adopting the best educational practices from around the world. Both cities have replaced the "key schools" system with more interactive teaching methods and technology, and have concentrated on raising the bar for all students through teacher training and mentorship.  Output (b) focuses on the fact that Shanghai and Hong Kong have a large pool of talented teachers to choose from and a large number of migrant children who are attending state schools. While these factors may contribute to their success, they do not fully capture the comprehensive approach that both cities have taken to improve their education systems.  Therefore, Output (a) is better as it provides a more comprehensive explanation of the reasons behind Shanghai and Hong Kong's educational success compared to Output (b).|||Scientist:Output (a) is better. Therefore, Output (a) is better as it provides a more comprehensive and informative explanation of the factors that have led to Shanghai and Hong Kong's exceptional education performance.|||Critic:After evaluating the two outputs, I find that Output (a) is better. It covers the importance of education, the adoption of best practices, competitive university entrance examinations, strong teacher training programs, and the concentration of talent in these cities. This comprehensive explanation allows the reader to understand the various factors that contribute to the success of these two cities' education systems. While the summary is concise and easy to understand, it does not provide the same level of depth and insight into the factors that contribute to the success of these two cities' education systems.  Therefore, Output (a) is better as it provides a more comprehensive and informative explanation of the factors that have led to Shanghai and Hong Kong's exceptional education performance. However, Output (a) offers a more comprehensive and accurate summary by including information about the high levels of pollution in the UK, the substances that make up the pollution, and the WHO's guidelines for safe air quality. It also mentions the legal action taken by the EU against the UK for persistently over the safe limit for air pollution. Output (b) focuses more on the number of deaths associated with air pollution and the fact that the UK is not alone in struggling to meet air quality targets. Output (a) provides a detailed description of the symptoms of prosopagnosia, which is important for understanding the condition. It also mentions the two main forms of the condition, which are developmental and acquired prosopagnosia. Developmental prosopagnosia affects around 2% of the population and is thought to be caused by a specific type of brain damage. Acquired prosopagnosia is much rarer and is caused by damage to the back of the brain on the right-hand side in an area generally known as the right occipito-temporal region.  Output (b) also provides a good summary of the symptoms of prosopagnosia, but it is not as comprehensive as Output (a). It states that people with prosopagnosia cannot recognize faces, but it does not mention the difficulty in recognizing gestures or emotions, which is an important aspect of the condition. Additionally, Output (b) does not mention the two main forms of prosopagnosia or the fact that there is no cure for the condition.  Therefore, Output (a) is better because it provides a more comprehensive and accurate summary of the symptoms of prosopagnosia.|||Critic:Output (a) is better. Output (b) is a good summary, but it is not as comprehensive as Output (a). Therefore, Output (a) is better for summarizing the symptoms of prosopagnosia.  Output (a) provides a detailed description of the symptoms of prosopagnosia, which is important for understanding the condition. It also mentions the two main forms of the condition, which are developmental and acquired prosopagnosia. Developmental prosopagnosia affects around 2% of the population and is thought to be caused by a specific type of brain damage. Acquired prosopagnosia is much rarer and is caused by damage to the back of the brain on the right-hand side in an area generally known as the right occipito-temporal region.  Output (b) also provides a good summary of the symptoms of prosopagnosia, but it is not as comprehensive as Output (a). It states that people with prosopagnosia cannot recognize faces, but it does not mention the difficulty in recognizing gestures or emotions, which is an important aspect of the condition. Additionally, Output (b) does not mention the two main forms of prosopagnosia or the fact that there is no cure for the condition.  Therefore, Output (a) is better because it provides a more comprehensive and accurate summary of the symptoms of prosopagnosia.
General Public:Output (a) is better.  In Output (a), the symptoms of prosopagnosia are described as a condition where people cannot recognize faces, even of those they know well. They can see the eyes, nose, and mouth, but cannot process them as a whole. There are two main forms of prosopagnosia: developmental and acquired. Developmental affects around 2% of the population and acquired is much rarer, caused by damage to the back of the brain on the right-hand side. There is no cure for prosopagnosia, and people with the condition often develop strategies to cope with it. It highlights the difficulties faced by locals in accessing medical care and basic services, as well as the growing concern among them due to the increasing number of immigrants. This information is crucial in understanding the impact of immigrants on the local population.  Output (b) is also a good summary of the impact of immigrants on Brazilian locals, but it does not provide as much detail as Output (a) regarding the impact on the local population. Therefore, Output (a) is the better choice in this case.  Therefore, Output (a) is better.

Output (b) provides a more detailed description of the difficulties faced by those seeking shelter and the impact on the local community, but it does not address the main reason for seeking shelter in Brazil. Therefore, Output (a) is better at summarizing the main reason for seeking shelter in Brazil.|||Critic:Output (a) is better. This summary effectively conveys the emotions and experiences of the mothers, providing a clear overview of their feelings and experiences as a whole. On the other hand, "Output (b)" focuses more on the individual stories of the mothers, which is not as comprehensive as "Output (a)". Therefore, "Output (a)" is a better summary of the feelings of being a new mother in 2020.  Therefore, Output (a) is better.

General Public:Output (a) is better.  Explanation: Both Output (a) and Output (b) provide information about UNICEF's role in India's polio eradication efforts. However, Output (a) provides more specific details about UNICEF's initiatives and strategies, such as the Social Mobilisation Network for polio, which was established in response to resistance against the polio vaccine. Output (a) also highlights the importance of micro-plans and community mobilizers in making polio vaccination more acceptable among people who had been resisting it. Additionally, Output (a) emphasizes the need for continued efforts to ensure that children remain protected against polio until the disease is eradicated globally. Overall, Output (a) provides a more comprehensive and detailed account of UNICEF's role in India's polio eradication efforts.|||Scientist:Output (a) is better.  Explanation: As a Scientist, I evaluated both Output (a) and Output (b) based on the given instruction to summarize the role of UNICEF in India's polio eradication efforts. Output (a) provides a more comprehensive and detailed account of UNICEF's role in India's polio eradication efforts. It highlights the Social Mobilisation Network for polio, which was established in response to resistance against the polio vaccine. The network worked with community mobilizers to promote hand-washing, hygiene, sanitation, exclusive breastfeeding, diarrhoea management, and routine immunization. Output (a) also emphasizes the importance of micro-plans and community mobilizers in making polio vaccination more acceptable among people who had been resisting it. Additionally, it highlights the need for continued efforts to ensure that children remain protected against polio until the disease is eradicated globally.  Output (b) provides information about UNICEF's role in India's successful efforts to eradicate polio. However, it does not provide as much detail as Output (a) about UNICEF's initiatives and strategies. Therefore, Output (a) is better in terms of providing a more comprehensive and detailed account of UNICEF's role in India's polio eradication efforts.|||Critic:Therefore, Output (a) is better. General Public:Output (a) is better.  In the given article, UNICEF played a crucial role in India's polio eradication efforts. The organization set up the Social Mobilisation Network in 2001 to address resistance against the polio vaccine in certain areas. UNICEF worked closely with the Indian government, Rotary clubs, and the World Health Organization to implement innovative strategies and engage with communities, religious leaders, and marginalized populations. The organization's holistic approach, which included promoting hand-washing, hygiene, sanitation, and routine immunization, contributed significantly to India's successful control of polio. Therefore, Output (a) is better as it provides a more detailed and comprehensive summary of UNICEF's role in India's polio eradication efforts.|||Scientist:Output (a) is better.  In the given article, UNICEF played a crucial role in India's polio eradication efforts. The organization set up the Social Mobilisation Network in 2001 to address resistance against the polio vaccine in certain areas. UNICEF worked closely with the Indian government, Rotary clubs, and the World Health Organization to implement innovative strategies and engage with communities, religious leaders, and marginalized populations. The organization's holistic approach, which included promoting hand-washing, hygiene, sanitation, and routine immunization, contributed significantly to India's successful control of polio. Therefore, Output (a) provides a more detailed and comprehensive summary of UNICEF's role in India's polio eradication efforts.|||Critic:Output (a) is better.  In the given article, UNICEF played a crucial role in India's polio eradication efforts. Output (a) provides a more detailed and comprehensive summary of UNICEF's role in India's polio eradication efforts. It highlights the organization's key initiatives, such as setting up the Social Mobilisation Network in 2001, working closely with the Indian government, Rotary clubs, and the World Health Organization, and implementing innovative strategies to engage with communities, religious leaders, and marginalized populations. Output (a) also emphasizes the importance of UNICEF's holistic approach, which included promoting hand-washing, hygiene, sanitation, and routine immunization, in contributing to India's successful control of polio.  Output (b) is a good summary of UNICEF's role in India's polio eradication efforts, but it is less detailed and comprehensive than Output (a). Output (b) focuses mainly on UNICEF's role in addressing resistance against the polio vaccine in certain areas, without providing a clear overview of the organization's broader efforts and strategies. Therefore, Output (a) is better as it provides a more detailed and comprehensive summary of UNICEF's role in India's polio eradication efforts.|||General Public:Therefore, Output (a) is better. General Public:Output (a) is better.  In Output (a), the opening line-ups of the Home centre are described as showcasing contemporary, intelligent works with a strong international flavour but rooted in Manchester. This accurately reflects the content of the opening line-ups, which include a play adaptation by Stockport playwright Simon Stephens, an art exhibition inspired by the play with artists from Egypt, Iceland, Kosovo, and Manchester, and inventive screenings of funfair-themed films. The output also highlights the economic benefits of the Home centre, with new restaurants, a hotel, and offices moving in due to its presence.  Output (b), on the other hand, does not provide a clear summary of the opening line-ups and their impacts. Instead, it focuses on the idea of Manchester being positioned as the de facto capital of the "Northern Powerhouse" and comparing it to Barcelona and Madrid. General Public:Output (a) is better.  In the given article, Manchester City Council is optimistic about the Home centre's potential to boost the economy and help Manchester become a cultural powerhouse. They believe that the centre will attract new businesses and contribute to the city's growth. The council also compares Manchester to Barcelona, suggesting that the city could become an "alternative centre of gravity" rather than a rival to London. This view aligns with the idea that Manchester is on a journey to become a cultural hub, and the Home centre is seen as a significant step in that direction.|||Scientist:Output (a) is better.  In the given article, Manchester City Council is optimistic about the Home centre's potential to boost the economy and help Manchester become a cultural powerhouse. They believe that the centre will attract new businesses and contribute to the city's growth. The council also compares Manchester to Barcelona, suggesting that the city could become an "alternative centre of gravity" rather than a rival to London. This view aligns with the idea that Manchester is on a journey to become a cultural hub, and the Home centre is seen as a significant step in that direction.  Output (b) argues that Manchester City Council believes the Home centre will be a catalyst for regeneration, attracting other businesses to the area and boosting the economy. They also hope that it will help Manchester become a cultural powerhouse to rival London, with a critical mass of culture that other cities outside London cannot match. They see Manchester as an "alternative centre of gravity" rather than a rival to the capital, and compare the relationship between Manchester and London to that of Barcelona and Madrid.  While both outputs convey the council's optimism about the Home centre, Output (a) provides a more concise summary of the council's views. It focuses on the council's belief that the Home centre will help Manchester become a cultural powerhouse and attract new businesses, which aligns with the original requirement to summarize the council's opinion on the Home centre. Therefore, Output (a) is better.|||Critic:Therefore, Output (a) is better. This aligns better with the original requirement to summarize the council's opinion on the Home centre.  Output (b) provides a more detailed summary, mentioning the council's hope that the Home centre will help Manchester become a cultural powerhouse to rival London, with a critical mass of culture that other cities outside London cannot match. They also compare Manchester to Barcelona, suggesting that the city could become an "alternative centre of gravity" rather than a rival to London. They also compare Manchester to Barcelona, suggesting that the city could become an "alternative centre of gravity" rather than a rival to London. While this information is relevant, it is not as directly related to the council's opinion on the Home centre as the points mentioned in Output (a).  Therefore, Output (a) is a better summary of Manchester City Council's opinion on the Home centre, as it focuses on the council's belief that the Home centre will help Manchester become a cultural powerhouse and attract new businesses.|||Scientist:In my evaluation, both Output (a) and Output (b) provide a clear summary of Manchester City Council's opinion on the Home centre. However, Output (a) is more concise and focuses on the council's belief that the Home centre will help Manchester become a cultural powerhouse and attract new businesses. This aligns better with the original requirement to summarize the council's opinion on the Home centre.  Output (b) provides a more detailed summary, mentioning the council's hope that the Home centre will help Manchester become a cultural powerhouse to rival London, with a critical mass of culture that other cities outside London cannot match. They also compare Manchester to Barcelona, suggesting that the city could become an "alternative centre of gravity" rather than a rival to London. In the given article, Manchester City Council is portrayed as the driving force behind the Home centre, which they hope will boost the economy and make Manchester a cultural powerhouse. The council believes that the arts can be a catalyst for regeneration and attract businesses to the area. Output (b) highlights Manchester City Council's belief that the Home centre will be a catalyst for regeneration, attracting other businesses to the area and boosting the economy. They also hope that it will help Manchester become a cultural powerhouse to rival London, with a critical mass of culture that other cities outside London cannot match. They see Manchester as an "alternative centre of gravity" rather than a rival to the capital, and compare the relationship between Manchester and London to that of Barcelona and Madrid.  Therefore, Output (b) is better.|||Critic:Therefore, Output (b) is better. It replaces the Cornerhouse cinema and gallery and Library Theatre, which have merged and been upgraded in the process. Home's launch follows the reopening of the Whitworth gallery after a £19m expansion and precedes plans for a new £78m venue called The Factory. The centre aims to boost the economy by attracting other businesses to its part of the city centre and serve as an example of how arts can be a catalyst for regeneration. While this information is interesting, it does not directly address the requirement of summarizing the basic information of Home. Therefore, Output (a) is better in terms of summarizing the basic information of Manchester's new arts centre Home.  As a General Public, I would like to agree with the previous referee's argument. Output (a) provides a concise summary of the basic information of Home, which is what I am looking for. It highlights the key features of Home and its potential impact on the city center, making it a useful update on the investigation. Therefore, I choose Output (a) as the better one. Therefore, Output (a) is better.|||Scientist:After evaluating the two outputs, I find that Output (a) is better. General Public:Output (a) is better.  In the article, Ronan Barry, the head of British American Tobacco's Brussels lobbying operation, is quoted as saying that his company is always open and honest in their lobbying efforts and that tobacco companies have as much right to meet MEPs as any other business. He also states that the scale of the tobacco lobby is often exaggerated and that there are at least as many lobbyists arguing against their positions as there are for them. Barry argues that they sell a legal product and are a legal company, therefore they have a role to play in communicating their point of view to decision-makers. This statement aligns with the idea that tobacco companies have the right to lobby and that their lobbying efforts should be considered on par with other industries.|||Scientist:Output (a) is better.  In the article, Ronan Barry, the head of British American Tobacco's Brussels lobbying operation, is quoted as saying that his company is always open and honest in their lobbying efforts and that tobacco companies have as much right to meet MEPs as any other business. He also states that the scale of the tobacco lobby is often exaggerated and that there are at least as many lobbyists arguing against their positions as there are for them. Barry argues that they sell a legal product and are a legal company, therefore they have a role to play in communicating their point of view to decision-makers. This statement aligns with the idea that tobacco companies have the right to lobby and that their lobbying efforts should be considered on par with other industries.  Output (b) is also a valid response, as it presents the same information as Output (a). However, as a Scientist, I would prioritize the accuracy and honesty of the information presented. Additionally, qubits can influence each other even when they're not physically connected, giving them the ability to make logical leaps that conventional computers cannot.  Output (b) states that quantum computers have the potential to solve complex computational problems much faster than conventional computers, which could speed up the discovery of new medicines, crack complex cryptographic security systems, design new materials, model climate change, and supercharge artificial intelligence. It effectively highlights the skills and technological advancements of the Anglo-Saxon smiths, the quality and purpose of the items, and the importance of the hoard in providing archaeological proof of the existence of elite warriors. The summary is well-structured, with clear sentences and good wording, making it easy to understand the main points.  Output (b) provides a more detailed description of the items found in the hoard, but it is less concise and informative than Output (a). The structure of the summary is also less clear, with some sentences being longer and more complex than necessary.  Therefore, Output (a) is better as it provides a more concise and informative summary of the key points about the Staffordshire Hoard and the Anglo-Saxons. General Public:Output (a) is better.  In Output (a), the article provides a clear summary of the measures retailer companies have taken to cope with Brexit. It highlights that some EU specialist online retailers have stopped delivering to the UK, while international shipping companies have imposed additional charges on shipments between the UK and the EU. The article also mentions that other firms have temporarily closed their stores from UK-based customers until their UK VAT registration and the overall process of selling to the UK post-Brexit has been sorted out. This summary effectively captures the main points of the original article and provides a clear and concise overview of the situation.  Output (b), on the other hand, does not provide a comprehensive summary of the measures retailer companies have taken to cope with Brexit. The "One Ford Plan" was a decision made by Ford HQ in 2008 to operate as a global company, with the same models selling across the world and investment going to the most efficient plants. This meant that Ford's plants in the UK had to compete globally, leading to a more challenging landscape for Bridgend engine plant. Output (b) is a slightly more concise version of the same information, but Output (a) provides more context and clarity on the implications of the decision.|||Scientist:Output (a) is better. The "One Ford Plan" was a decision made by Ford HQ in 2008 to operate as a global company, with the same models selling across the world and investment going to the most efficient plants. This meant that Ford's plants in the UK had to compete globally, leading to a more challenging landscape for Bridgend engine plant. Output (b) is a slightly more concise version of the same information, but Output (a) provides more context and clarity on the implications of the decision.  Output (b) is better.  The "One Ford Plan" was a decision made by Ford HQ in 2008 to operate as a global company, with the same models selling across the world. This meant that factories making engines in the UK would have to be more efficient to compete globally. Output (a) provides more context and clarity on the implications of the decision, but Output (b) is a more concise version of the same information.  Therefore, Output (a) is better.|||General Public:Therefore, Output (a) is better. The article discusses various definitions of collusion provided by different people, including Sir John Stevens, Canadian judge Peter Cory, the first police ombudsman for Northern Ireland Nuala O'Loan, and others. Despite some differences in emphasis, all of the definitions generally agree that collusion involves an agreement or arrangement between individuals or organizations to achieve an unlawful or improper purpose, and may also involve deliberately ignoring or turning a blind eye to wrongful acts. Additionally, there is a consensus that collusion requires a deliberate act or omission, rather than mere negligence or incompetence.  Output (b) is better.  Output (a) is better. These definitions share several similarities, such as the presence of secret agreements or arrangements between individuals or organizations to achieve unlawful or improper purposes, the act of deliberately ignoring or turning a blind eye to wrongful acts, and the consideration of both active acts and omissions or failures to act as forms of collusion.  Output (a) summarizes these similarities effectively, stating that most definitions involve an agreement or arrangement between individuals or organizations to achieve an unlawful or improper purpose, and the deliberate ignoring or turning a blind eye to a known wrongdoing or misbehavior. Output (b), on the other hand, focuses more on the definitions provided by Lord Stevens and Peter Cory, which are similar but not identical to the definitions provided by the other people mentioned in the article. The number of UK fire and rescue staff taking long-term sick leave due to mental illness has risen by nearly a third over the last six years. 2. The figure has doubled in London since 2011-12. 3. At least 126 staff have left the service due to mental health issues since 2011. 4. In 2016-17, 97 Scottish fire staff took long-term mental health sick leave, while in Northern Ireland that figure was 111. Therefore, Output (a) is better.|||General Public:After evaluating the two outputs, I believe that Output (a) is better. General Public:Output (a) is better.  The article discusses the phenomenon of people dying shortly after their loved ones, citing two examples of couples who died within days of each other. It also notes that there is scientific evidence to support the idea that grief can cause heart problems, such as "broken heart syndrome" which can be caused by the sudden release of hormones like adrenaline. The article quotes Dr Sunil Shah of St George's at the University of London, who says that bereavement can have a direct effect on the heart, and the British Heart Foundation, which explains that "broken heart syndrome" is a temporary condition where the heart muscle becomes suddenly weakened or stunned. The article concludes by saying that while the phenomenon of people dying shortly after their loved ones is tragic, it also often brings relief to the surviving family members.|||Scientist:Therefore, Output (a) is better. General Public:Output (a) is better.  In the article, Dr. Sunil Shah of St George's at the University of London explains that bereavement can have a direct effect on the health of the heart. Their study found that the number of people who had a heart attack or stroke in the month after a loved one died was double that of a non-grieving control group. The British Heart Foundation states that "broken heart syndrome," or stress cardiomyopathy, is a temporary condition where the heart muscle becomes suddenly weakened or stunned, often brought on by a shock such as bereavement or other significant emotional or physical stress.  Output (b) provides a summary of the article, but it does not include the specific information about the study conducted by Dr. Sunil Shah and the British Heart Foundation's explanation of broken heart syndrome. Therefore, Output (a) is better as it provides more detailed information about the effects of bereavement on the heart.|||Scientist:Output (a) is better. In evaluating the two outputs, I considered whether they execute the instruction to summarize the potential benefits of deep sea mining, including the types and quantities of metals that can be extracted. Output (b) provides a more general overview of the potential benefits of deep sea mining, mentioning that it could provide a new source of valuable metals. Output (a), on the other hand, provides a more detailed summary of the potential benefits of deep sea mining, specifically mentioning the types and quantities of metals that can be extracted, such as manganese, nickel, copper, and cobalt. Therefore, Output (b) is better for summarizing the potential benefits of deep sea mining in terms of the metals that can be extracted.
